title: Complications of the Common Cold
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: You’ve got a cough , your throat’s sore, and your nose is stuffed up. Sounds like a cold, right?

It might be something more than that if you’ve been sniffly for over a week, or if your symptoms seem to be getting worse. Here’s how to get a sense of what might be making you feel under the weather.

content_blocks.text: You’ve got a cough , your throat’s sore, and your nose is stuffed up. Sounds like a cold, right?

It might be something more than that if you’ve been sniffly for over a week, or if your symptoms seem to be getting worse. Here’s how to get a sense of what might be making you feel under the weather.

sections.heading: Is It Just a Common Cold?
content: These typically last 3 to 10 days. You could have symptoms like:
Try to rest up while the cold runs its course. There's probably no need to call your doctor unless your symptoms are severe or you have other medical problems.
bullets: A runny nose -- with or without green or yellow mucus

content_blocks.text: These typically last 3 to 10 days. You could have symptoms like:
associated_bullets: A runny nose -- with or without green or yellow mucus

content_blocks.text: Try to rest up while the cold runs its course. There's probably no need to call your doctor unless your symptoms are severe or you have other medical problems.

sections.heading: When Should I Call the Doctor?
content: Pick up the phone if you have any of these symptoms. It could mean you have something more than a cold:
Call 911 for any of these problems:
bullets: Fever higher than 102 F with tiredness and body aches
Severe sinus pain in your face or forehead
Swollen glands in your neck or jaw
Trouble breathing or shortness of breath

content_blocks.text: Pick up the phone if you have any of these symptoms. It could mean you have something more than a cold:
associated_bullets: Fever higher than 102 F with tiredness and body aches
Severe sinus pain in your face or forehead
Swollen glands in your neck or jaw

content_blocks.text: Call 911 for any of these problems:
associated_bullets: Trouble breathing or shortness of breath

sections.heading: What Else Could It Be?
content: Sometimes a cold causes swelling in the sinuses or lungs . That can lead to other problems, like these:

Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) : This happens when a cold virus infects your sinuses -- the hollow areas in the bones of your cheeks, forehead, and under your eyes . These areas swell, and your body makes more mucus. It’s a perfect place for bacteria to grow and thrive. You may get a headache, fever, and some or all of these symptoms:
See your doctor if these symptoms are severe, you still feel bad after 7 days, or if you get better and then get worse.
bullets: Less sense of smell and taste
Pain or pressure near your sinuses that gets worse when you bend over
A cough that’s worse at night

content_blocks.text: Sometimes a cold causes swelling in the sinuses or lungs . That can lead to other problems, like these:

Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) : This happens when a cold virus infects your sinuses -- the hollow areas in the bones of your cheeks, forehead, and under your eyes . These areas swell, and your body makes more mucus. It’s a perfect place for bacteria to grow and thrive. You may get a headache, fever, and some or all of these symptoms:
associated_bullets: Less sense of smell and taste
Pain or pressure near your sinuses that gets worse when you bend over
A cough that’s worse at night

content_blocks.text: See your doctor if these symptoms are severe, you still feel bad after 7 days, or if you get better and then get worse.

Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) : This happens when a cold virus infects your sinuses -- the hollow areas in the bones of your cheeks, forehead, and under your eyes . See your doctor if these symptoms are severe, you still feel bad after 7 days, or if you get better and then get worse.

A cough that’s worse at night

content_blocks.text: Sometimes a cold causes swelling in the sinuses or lungs . That can lead to other problems, like these:

Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) : This happens when a cold virus infects your sinuses -- the hollow areas in the bones of your cheeks, forehead, and under your eyes . These areas swell, and your body makes more mucus. It’s a perfect place for bacteria to grow and thrive. You may get a headache, fever, and some or all of these symptoms:

content: Get emergency medical help right away if you have one or more of these problems. They could be warning signs of something more serious, like meningitis :
bullets: Sudden, severe pain in the face or head
Shortness of breath (in cases of severe meningitis)

content_blocks.text: Get emergency medical help right away if you have one or more of these problems. They could be warning signs of something more serious, like meningitis :
associated_bullets: Sudden, severe pain in the face or head
Shortness of breath (in cases of severe meningitis)

sections.heading: Bronchitis
content: (a chest cold) : You get it when the large tubes that carry air into your lungs become swollen and irritated. Telltale symptoms of this illness can include:
Most of the time, you don’t need to see a doctor for bronchitis. But call yours ASAP if you have any of these symptoms -- you could have pneumonia :
Get emergency care or call 911 for any of these symptoms:
If you’re over age 75 and have a cough that won’t stop, see your doctor. You could have bronchitis, even if you don’t have any other symptoms.
Ear infection : Colds and sinus infections can keep fluid trapped in your ear behind your eardrum. When this happens, bacteria or viruses can grow and cause an infection.
bullets: A cough that could last 10 to 20 days
A cough that produces green, yellow, or clear mucus
A cough that is not better after 7 to 10 days
Chest pain or trouble breathing with your cough

content_blocks.text: (a chest cold) : You get it when the large tubes that carry air into your lungs become swollen and irritated. Telltale symptoms of this illness can include:
associated_bullets: A cough that could last 10 to 20 days
A cough that produces green, yellow, or clear mucus

content_blocks.text: Most of the time, you don’t need to see a doctor for bronchitis. But call yours ASAP if you have any of these symptoms -- you could have pneumonia :
associated_bullets: A cough that is not better after 7 to 10 days

content_blocks.text: Get emergency care or call 911 for any of these symptoms:
associated_bullets: Chest pain or trouble breathing with your cough

content_blocks.text: If you’re over age 75 and have a cough that won’t stop, see your doctor. You could have bronchitis, even if you don’t have any other symptoms.
Ear infection : Colds and sinus infections can keep fluid trapped in your ear behind your eardrum. When this happens, bacteria or viruses can grow and cause an infection.

content: Warning signs of an ear infection can include:
See your doctor right away if you have a high fever or severe pain in your ear. Hacking and sneezing are normal when you have a cold. Other problems, like a high fever, aren’t.
If any of your symptoms concern you, put your mind at ease -- call the doctor.
bullets: Fullness or pressure in one or both ears
Pain in one or both of them
Fluid that drains from your ear

content_blocks.text: Warning signs of an ear infection can include:
associated_bullets: Fullness or pressure in one or both ears
Pain in one or both of them
Fluid that drains from your ear

content_blocks.text: See your doctor right away if you have a high fever or severe pain in your ear. Hacking and sneezing are normal when you have a cold. Other problems, like a high fever, aren’t.
If any of your symptoms concern you, put your mind at ease -- call the doctor.

bullets: Sudden, severe pain in the face or head
Shortness of breath (in cases of severe meningitis)

sources: UpToDate: “Patient information: The common cold in adults (beyond the basics).”
Cleveland Clinic: “Sinus Infections That Don’t Quit: When You Should Worry.”
UpToDate: “Patient information: Acute bronchitis in adults (beyond the basics).”
University of Rochester Medical Center: “Otitis Media (Middle-Ear Infection) in Adults.”
meta_description: The common cold is usually no cause for concern, but it can sometimes lead to more serious issues. WebMD shares tips on how to know when to call a doctor.
